item.title: The Olympics Are a Show Of Global Harmony. The World is Anything But.
item.description: The Winter Games, which officially open in Italy on Friday, are rooted in international cooperation. That feels out of place to some in a world where old rules no longer apply.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:description: The Olympic rings in Livigno, Italy.

item.title: Iran Is at Work on Missile and Nuclear Sites, Satellite Images Show
item.description: Repairs at key missile sites began soon after they were hit by Israeli and U.S. strikes last year, but work at Iran’s nuclear facilities has been slower.
item.dc:creator: Samuel Granados and Aurelien Breeden

item.title: She’s Upending Japanese Politics With Two Words: ‘I’m Pregnant’
item.description: Hikaru Fujita, who’s running in Sunday’s parliamentary election, is a standout in a country where expectant mothers rarely enter national politics.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández and Kiuko Notoya
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hikaru Fujita, a candidate for Parliament, in Azumino City, Nagano Prefecture, on Tuesday.

item.title: Russian General Is Shot in Latest Attack on a Top Military Leader in Moscow
item.description: Lt. Gen. Vladimir Alekseyev provided intelligence to the Kremlin for Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and had been penalized by the U.S. twice, including for meddling in elections.
item.dc:creator: Nataliya Vasilyeva
item.media:description: A still image from a video released by the Russian Ministry of Defense showing Lt. Gen. Vladimir Alekseyev in 2023. An attacker shot him in the back, the authorities said on Friday.

item.title: Trump Says Talks With Iran Were Good, but There’s More Work to Do
item.description: President Trump said the negotiations would resume next week. Abbas Araghchi, the Iranian foreign minister, said the talks were off to a “good start.”
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden and Leily Nikounazar
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Suicide Bombing Kills 31 at Mosque in Pakistan’s Capital
item.description: The bombing, during Friday prayers, was the second major attack in recent months in Islamabad, raising concerns that extremist violence is spreading far from Pakistan’s border areas.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Netanyahu Suggests Other Officials to Blame for Oct. 7 Failings
item.description: In a document released on Thursday night, the Israeli leader sought to distance himself from responsibility for intelligence and security failings before the Hamas-led attack.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, center, and President Isaac Herzog, right, at a memorial last week for Ran Gvili, an off-duty police officer killed during the Oct. 7, 2023, attack.

item.title: China Reverses Death Sentence for Canadian in a Small Win for Carney
item.description: The ruling by China’s highest court followed a recent meeting between China and Canada’s top leaders that led to a thaw in the two countries’ relations.
item.dc:creator: Lily Kuo
item.media:credit: Intermediate Peoples' Court of Dalian, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Robert Lloyd Schellenberg in 2019 during his retrial on drug-trafficking charges in a court in Dalian, China.

item.title: Norway Rallies Behind Royals, Despite Dismay Over Epstein Links
item.description: The future queen’s links to Jeffrey Epstein, and her son’s rape trial, have disappointed many Norwegians. But there is still widespread support for the monarchy.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Crown Princess Mette-Marit of Norway with her husband, Crown Prince Haakon.

item.title: As Olympics Open, Pope Warns Against Using Sports for ‘Propaganda’
item.description: The Milan-Cortina Games are overlapping with a moment of geopolitical turbulence as conflicts rage, national leaders issue threats and alliances are strained.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Olympic rings in the Olympic Village in Cortina d’Ampezzo, Italy.

item.title: What to Expect at the Olympic Opening Ceremonies, From the Man Behind Them
item.description: Marco Balich has helped design grand spectacles at more than half a dozen Olympics. On Friday, he’ll do it again, on home turf in Italy.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Rehearsing for the opening ceremony of the 2026 Winter Olympics, in Milan last week.

item.title: Starmer Apologizes for Ex-Ambassador Mandelson’s Epstein Ties
item.description: Newly released documents detailed connections between the convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein and Peter Mandelson, who was picked to be the U.S. envoy by the British prime minister, Keir Starmer.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain has vowed to hold Peter Mandelson accountable and has apologized to Jeffrey Epstein’s victims.

item.title: ‘It’s Collective Punishment’: Iran Exacts Heavy Price on Protest Supporters
item.description: The authorities are making mass arrests, seizing assets and hunting down doctors who treated protesters. Some Iranians keep showing defiance anyway.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon, Leily Nikounazar and Sanam Mahoozi
item.media:description: Members of an Iranian counterterrorism police unit at a pro-government rally in Tehran last month.

item.title: Thousands Displaced by Military Operation in Pakistan
item.description: Some 60,000 evacuees have been left in limbo by confusion and political disputes as Pakistan battles insurgents on its border with Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman

item.title: Olympics Officials Signal Sanctions on Russia in Sports May End
item.description: In Milan this week, Olympics officials signaled a willingness to ease years of restrictions imposed on the country over its state-backed doping program and invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Tariq Panja
item.media:description: Athletes competing for the Russian Olympic Committee in the men’s ice hockey gold medal match at the 2022 Winter Olympics in Beijing. The team won a silver medal.

item.title: Philippe Morillon, General Who Made Fateful Protection Promise, Dies at 90
item.description: “I will never abandon you,” he told residents of Srebrenica amid sectarian armed conflict in Bosnia. The town later suffered the worst massacre in Europe since World War II.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia
item.media:description: Gen. Philippe Morillon in 1993, as commander of U.N. forces in what was then Bosnia-Herzegovina.

item.title: How Is Security Different at These Olympic Games?
item.description: Our sports correspondent Tariq Panja talks with Katrin Bennhold about the security at the Olympics in Italy, including the presence of Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents, who the U.S. says are there only in an advisory role.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja, Katrin Bennhold, Leila Medina and Laura Salaberry

item.title: JD Vance Is Booed at Winter Olympics Opening Ceremony in Milan
item.description: Before the event, protesters marched in Milan in opposition to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, whose personnel are in Italy to advise local officials in securing the Winter Games.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn
item.media:description: Vice President JD Vance and Usha Vance at San Siro stadium for the opening ceremony of the Winter Olympics in Milan on Friday.

item.title: In the Grip of Gangs, Haiti Faces a Government Leadership Vacuum
item.description: The tenure of a presidential council that has been running Haiti expires on Saturday. It’s unclear what will come next.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles, David C. Adams and André Paultre
item.media:description: A view from inside an armored police vehicle showing cars burned by armed gangs and used as a barricade on a deserted street Port-au-Prince, Haiti, last month.

item.title: Saalumarada Thimmakka Dies; Planted and Nurtured Thousands of Trees
item.description: Believed to be 113, she spent decades building an environmental legacy in India, inspired by her grief at being unable to conceive children.
item.dc:creator: Pragati K.B.

item.title: A dozen U.S. figure skaters march in the ceremony, some fresh off competing.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur
item.media:description: Alysa Liu, the reigning world champion, is among the members of the U.S. Figure Skating team marching in the opening ceremony of the Olympic Games.

item.title: The U.S. flag bearers are a renowned speedskater and a bobsledder, both previous Olympians.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur

item.title: France and Canada Open Consulates in Greenland, Following Trump Threats
item.description: Greenland’s mini diplomatic scene is about to get more lively as Canada and France set up consulates, following threats by President Trump to take over the island.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Maya Tekeli
item.media:description: The opening of the Canadian Consulate in a building shared with the Icelandic consulate in Nuuk, Greenland, on Friday.

item.title: Flying Solo: Some Olympic Athletes Are Their Country’s Whole Team
item.description: At the Winter Games, athletes from 15 different nations are the only competitor from their countries.
item.dc:creator: Heather Knight
item.media:description: Four years ago, at age 17, Aruwin Salehhuddin became the first female athlete to represent Malaysia at the Olympics. But there was a male athlete, too, and they carried the flag together. This year, she will be carrying it alone.

item.title: Haiti Just Won the Fashion Game at the Opening Ceremonies
item.description: The athletes from the Caribbean nation wanted their appearances to honor their country’s heritage. The result is looks that stand out.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.media:description: Stella Jean, center, a Haitian-Italian designer based in Milan, designed the looks of Haiti’s national team.

item.title: In Talks, Trump Won’t Allow Iran to Have Any Enriched Uranium
item.description: Can the two sides get past Iran’s claim that it has a “right” to enrich uranium?
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Workers at a uranium conversion facility in Isfahan, Iran, in 2005. Analysts say Iran’s position on enrichment reflects the country’s intense pride in a nuclear program that has become a symbol of Iranian independence.

item.title: The ghost of Giorgio Armani hovers over the Games.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.media:description: Three lines of models in red, white and green Armani looks walking the stadium “runway” during the opening ceremonies.

item.title: Scattered protests occur in Milan before the ceremonies begin.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn and Tariq Panja
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the hours leading up to the Winter Games, demonstrators protesting in the San Siro district of Milan.

item.title: 2026 Winter Olympics Opening Ceremonies Performers: Mariah Carey, Andrea Bocelli and More
item.description: The performers include an Italian tenor who is one of the most successful singers in the world and an actress who has had roles in “The White Lotus” and “The Paper.”
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather and Joshua Barone

item.title: Mariah Carey Performs at Winter Olympics Opening Ceremony in Milan
item.description: The singer-songwriter “perfectly embodies the emotional spirit of the Games,” Olympic organizers said.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz, Victor Mather and Alex Marshall
item.media:description: Mariah Carey is one of the best-selling recording artists of all time.

item.title: Who will light the Olympic cauldrons?
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather

item.title: No Fashion Focus in Milan After France Made It Part of Summer Olympics
item.description: In Paris, the fashion powerhouse LVMH was a headline sponsor and helped design the medals and the athletes’ apparel.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.category: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton SA
item.media:description: Lady Gaga performing before the opening ceremony of the Paris Olympic Games.

item.title: Milan Athletes Welcome Return of Winter Olympics Spectators
item.description: At the last Winter Games, in 2022 in Beijing, the coronavirus pandemic meant that spectators were largely absent and competing was a lonely experience.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Empty seats at the speedskating finals during the 2022 Winter Olympics in Beijing.

item.title: A Lightweight, Minimalist Torch Design Helps Kick Off the Winter Games
item.description: The opening ceremonies will also have two cauldron lightings for the first time. One will be in Milan, the other in Cortina d’Ampezzo.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Italian ballet dancer Roberto Bolle receiving the Olympic torch in Milan on Friday. The torch passed through some 300 towns and more than 60 UNESCO World Heritage Sites.

item.title: The Olympics Could Be One of the Last Big Events for an Iconic Milan Stadium
item.description: The San Siro stadium is a temple of soccer and one of the city’s most beloved monuments, but its days may be numbered.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Outside San Siro stadium in Milan. The Winter Olympics may be one of its last global events.

item.title: Naturally, Italy’s Song for the Olympics Is About Love
item.description: The 1977 classic “Ti Amo” was so popular that it was recorded in several languages. Now, it takes a spin as the official song for the 2026 Winter Olympics.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Running to catch up with the torchbearer in Milan on Friday.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather and Motoko Rich

item.title: Milan Winter Olympics Opening Ceremony: What Time to Watch, How to Watch, and More
item.description: They will take place at 2 p.m. Eastern on Friday across four separate venues in Northern Italy.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn
item.media:description: A training session at Livigno Snow Park in Italy on Wednesday.

item.title: Argentina and U.S. Sign Sweeping Trade Deal as Alliance Deepens
item.description: The deal reduces reciprocal tariffs and expands quotas for key trading goods, including Argentine beef — a flashpoint for American ranchers.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: President Trump with President Javier Milei of Argentina at the White House in October.

item.title: Toronto Police Charged in Sweeping Drug and Corruption Case
item.description: After hit men targeted the home of a prison manager in June, investigators say, the schemes of a criminal network involving the police unraveled.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Jon Blacker/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: From left, Chief Myron Demkiw of the Toronto police, Chief Jim MacSween and Deputy Chief Ryan Hogan of the York Regional Police at a news conference on Thursday in Aurora, Ontario.

item.title: It’s Time for the Olympics
item.description: The Games are supposed to bring people from around the globe together, but there’s no escaping politics.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold

item.title: Italy Toughens Protest Laws, Hours Before Planned Rallies at Winter Olympics
item.description: The restrictions could affect people demonstrating this weekend outside Olympic events in northern Italy.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Outside San Siro Stadium in Milan, a venue for the 2026 Winter Olympic Games, on Wednesday.

item.title: At Ukraine’s Request, Starlink Denies Internet Access to Russian Troops
item.description: It’s unclear what effect the change will have on Russia’s ability to wage war, but Russian military bloggers said troops were experiencing internet outages that hampered frontline communications.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne and Maria Varenikova
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier preparing a Starlink satellite internet system in the Donetsk region in 2024. Russians have been evading export restrictions to smuggle in Starlink devices and send them to the front.

item.title: Mayor of Tequila, Mexico, Is Accused of Shaking Down Tequila Companies
item.description: The mayor of the city that is the birthplace of the bottled spirit is the latest official to be arrested as Mexico targets cartel-related corruption.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:credit: Lindsay Lauckner Gundlock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Blue agave, grown for tequila, in Jalisco state, Mexico.

item.title: At a Bonobo’s ‘Tea Party,’ Scientists Find Hints of Imagination
item.description: In a playtime experiment, researchers found that our closest living relatives have the capacity for make-believe, too.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Robles-Gil

item.title: How We Know Iran Crushed Protests with Lethal Force
item.description: The New York Times collected and analyzed hundreds of videos of a crackdown on anti-government protests that Iranians shared despite an internet blackout. Sanjana Varghese explains how the Visual Investigations team at The Times verified them.
item.dc:creator: Sanjana Varghese, Christina Thornell, James Surdam, Jon Hazell and Zach Caldwell

item.title: Carney Increases E.V. Investments as Trump’s Trade Policy Disrupts Canada’s Auto Industry
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney announced several measures Thursday aimed at making Canada a global leader in electric vehicles and rescuing an industry ravaged by U.S. trade policy.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Eduardo Lima/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada, right, visiting an auto parts plant on Thursday in Woodbridge, Ontario.

item.title: LA Olympics Chief Keeps Low Profile in Milan Games After Appearing in Epstein Files
item.description: Casey Wasserman, who is leading preparations for the 2028 Summer Games, has expressed “regret” after messages he exchanged with Ghislaine Maxwell decades ago surfaced.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja and Shawn Hubler
item.category: Los Angeles Organizing Committee for the Olympic and Paralympic Games 2028 (LA28)
item.media:description: Casey Wasserman, chairman of the 2028 Olympics in Los Angeles, addressing members of the International Olympic Committee in Milan on Tuesday.

item.title: The Louvre Thieves Dropped This Priceless Crown. Now It Looks Like This.
item.description: Empress Eugénie’s crown was left lying on the sidewalk after the Louvre Museum heist in October. The museum has now released pictures of the damage.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter

item.title: Deaths in Boat Disaster in English Channel Were Avoidable, Inquiry Finds
item.description: The report blamed people smugglers and “systemic failure” on the part of the authorities after about 30 people drowned as they tried to reach Britain from France in 2021.
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden
item.media:description: Belongings left by migrants near Wimereux, France, before they tried to cross the English Channel to reach Britain in November 2021.

item.title: Iranian Nobel Peace Laureate Starts New Hunger Strike in Prison
item.description: The rights activist Narges Mohammadi is protesting her continued detention, her family said. She was arrested again in December after being given leave from prison for medical treatment.
item.dc:creator: Sanam Mahoozi
item.media:credit: Nooshin Jafari/Middle East Images, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Narges Mohammadi in Tehran last year while on temporary leave from prison. She was released for medical treatment in 2024 before being arrested again last year.

item.title: Jessie Diggins is the Olympian Testing the Limits of Endurance
item.description: Jessie Diggins has become the best-ever American cross-country skier because of what she pushes her body through.
item.dc:creator: Reid Forgrave
item.media:credit: Holly Andres for The New York Times

item.title: Nuclear Arms Control Era Comes to End Amid Global Rush for New Weapons
item.description: Beijing, Moscow and shaken American allies are seeking new warheads as President Trump ends more than a half century of nuclear arms control with Russia.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and William J. Broad
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: President Trump meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Alaska last year.

item.title: Ukraine-Russia Talks End With Little Progress and Hints of Impasse
item.description: American negotiators trumpeted plans for a prisoner swap, but that was small recompense for months of diplomatic efforts by the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker
item.media:description: Working on Wednesday at a power plant in Kyiv, Ukraine, that was heavily damaged by recent Russian missile and drone strikes.

item.title: Residents of Cortina, a Winter Olympics Hub, Are Angry About All the Construction
item.description: In Cortina d’Ampezzo, a hub for the Games in northern Italy, some residents, including a former Olympian, are annoyed about all the construction. Others are annoyed that they’re annoyed.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Josephine de La Bruyère
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Laborers in Cortina d’Ampezzo working in January to finish a ski lift before the Winter Games begin.
